retest this please

Normally, all test cases should be independent to each other. So running order should make no difference to the result. But there are some cases that may left routes/IP on DUT or change the configuration of DUT, which may fail following cases. In such case, running them in alphabetic order enables us to analyze it more easily. Maybe we could add another command line option to toggle the dafault ```sort``` behavior.

agree with you that test cases should be independent to each other. but sometimes, we do want to make sure certain test cases can be run first for examle warm reboot so that we can test behavior after the warm reboot. but I think adding a command line option is probably a better design.

@Junchao-Mellanox: Since these methods are inherited from DeviceBase, there are other classes which inherit these methods. Even though they may not be used by the MIB, we should test that the APIs are implemented for completeness. Do you agree? If so, can you please add similar API tests to the following files and their respective helpers?

- test_component.py
- test_fan_drawer_fans.py
- test_module.py
- test_psu_fans.py

> @Junchao-Mellanox: Since these methods are inherited from DeviceBase, there are other classes which inherit these methods. @sanmalho-git Could you please help review?

> in line 35 - please add 'and return a single result'
> in line 37 - comment should be "Run 'foo' for asic_index=1, and return a single result.
> 
> When calling the module for multiple hosts, I believe it is not the ansible module that takes care of returning a dictionary. So, I would think line 44 should be something like:
> 
> {node.hostname: foo() for node in duthosts.frontend_nodes}
> 
> Similarly line 52 should be:
> {node.hostname: foo() for node in duthosts.frontend_nodes}
> 
> and line 56 should be
> {node.hostname: foo(asic_index=0) for node in duthosts.frontend_nodes}

Thanks for the comments! Updated.

Did some prototyping with the above requirements with bgp_facts ansible module and found the following issues:

- the return value in 'ansible_facts' cannot be a list, it has to be a dictionary. Get the following error

   ```
    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ansible/vars/clean.py", line 114, in remove_internal_keys\n    
                  for key in list(data.get(\'ansible_facts\', {}).keys()):\n
                  AttributeError: \'list\' object has no attribute \'keys\'\n', '_ansible_no_log': False, 'stdout': ''}
   ```

- For backward compatibility, we are returning a dictionary for a single asic. But, for multi-asic, we are returning a list (or a dictionary keyed by asic_index to avoid the first issue).  Have the following concerns with this:

   - The code in the ansible module becomes more complex to handle different data structures.
   - For a test to be able to run on both a single asic and a multi-asic DUT, then it would have to take care of the different data structures being returned depending and act appropriately.
      ```
      dut_bgp_facts = duthost.bpg_facts()['ansible_facts']
      if isinstance(dut_bgp_facts, list):
         # dealing with multi-asic box
      else:
         # dealing with single-asic box
      ```

- If asic_index is not specified, then we are checking asic.conf on the box in every call to the module to figure out the number of asics on this box.   

   - To check asic.conf, we would have to pass in 'platform' as well.
   - The number of asics is constant (static)  and doesn't change throughout the course of testing. 

   Instead of asic_index, we could pass 'facts' from SonicHost, which would eliminate the above issues and make it flexible for adding more things that potentially the modules need in the future.

Will continue to do some more prototyping to figure out a better solution.

> Did some prototyping with the above requirements with bgp_facts ansible module and found the following issues:
> 
> * the return value in 'ansible_facts' cannot be a list, it has to be a dictionary. Get the following error
>   ```
>    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ansible/vars/clean.py", line 114, in remove_internal_keys\n    
>                  for key in list(data.get(\'ansible_facts\', {}).keys()):\n
>                  AttributeError: \'list\' object has no attribute \'keys\'\n', '_ansible_no_log': False, 'stdout': ''}
>   ```
> * For backward compatibility, we are returning a dictionary for a single asic. But, for multi-asic, we are returning a list (or a dictionary keyed by asic_index to avoid the first issue).  Have the following concerns with this:
>   
>   * The code in the ansible module becomes more complex to handle different data structures.
>   * For a test to be able to run on both a single asic and a multi-asic DUT, then it would have to take care of the different data structures being returned depending and act appropriately.
>     ```
>     dut_bgp_facts = duthost.bpg_facts()['ansible_facts']
>     if isinstance(dut_bgp_facts, list):
>        # dealing with multi-asic box
>     else:
>        # dealing with single-asic box
>     ```
If the modules can always return a dictionary of facts which keyed by asic_index then the caller can be consistent.
Single Asic device, can have a special asic_index value.  

> * If asic_index is not specified, then we are checking asic.conf on the box in every call to the module to figure out the number of asics on this box.
>   
>   * To check asic.conf, we would have to pass in 'platform' as well.
>   * The number of asics is constant (static)  and doesn't change throughout the course of testing.
>   
>   Instead of asic_index, we could pass 'facts' from SonicHost, which would eliminate the above issues and make it flexible for adding more things that potentially the modules need in the future.
> 
I think this is a good approach. There are few the fact modules require both asic_index and namespace(asic_name), we could pass both of them instead converting in the module.


> Will continue to do some more prototyping to figure out a better solution.

It looks like Ansible requires that `ansible_facts` must be a dictionary. It's probably because Ansible needs to cleanup sensitive information in the results, like passwords, credentials.

In this case, the only approach is to always return a dictionary keyed by `asic_index`. Then all the existing scripts using these ansible modules need to be updated because we lost backward compatibility. The good side is that consumer of the modules can be consistent because the returned result is always a dictionary. Scripts supporting both single ASIC and multi_ASIC can be simpler.

I am hesitate with passing `facts` from SonicHost to ansible modules.
* On sonic switch, there is a package `sonic_py_common` which has two modules `device_info` and `multi_asic`. These two modules has functions like `get_num_npus` and `is_multi_npu`. These tools are used by many SONiC specific commands. The overhead of getting ASIC information using these tools in ansible module is trivial.
* It would be more explicit to pass information just needed by the ansible module, like `asic_index` or `namespace` or `asic_name`. Extra facts are not always needed by the modules.
* There are still cases that we just need to get facts of some specific ASIC. It looks redundant to pass both facts and asic_index to ansible module while calling them.

@sanmalho-git The approach you proposed looks pretty good to me. The complexity is hidden in the Nodes class. Returned results of ansible modules make sense for single/multiple nodes and single/multi ASICs. Meanwhile backward compatibility is maintained. We can update the test scripts and libs in incremental way.

retest this please

conftest.py, function generate_param_asic_index:
- doesn't handle multiple inventory files - eg --inventory "inventory1,inventory2"
- Within an inventory it is assuming all hosts are defined under "all.children.sonic.hosts".
```
hosts = inv['all']['children']['sonic']['hosts']
```
We have different box types, and have grouped our inventory based on the box types. For example:

```
all:
  children:
    sonic:
      children:
        sonic_type1:
        sonic_type2:
      vars:
        sonic_version: v2

sonic_type1:
  hosts:
    box1:
      ansible_host: xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
      num_asic: 3
    box2:
      ansible_host: xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
      num_asic: 3
```

If we want to add the 'num_asic' data to box1, it won't work.

One possible solution is to define a function that takes care of this situation as below.

```
def get_host_data(request, host):
    inv_files = [inv_file.strip() for inv_file in request.config.getoption("ansible_inventory").split(",")]
    for a_inv_file in inv_files:
        with open(a_inv_file, 'r') as fh:
            inv = yaml.safe_load(fh)
            if 'hosts' in inv['all']['children']['sonic']:
                hosts = inv['all']['children']['sonic']['hosts']
                if host in hosts:
                    return hosts[host]

            if 'children' in inv['all']['children']['sonic']:
                children = inv['all']['children']['sonic']['children']
                for a_child in children:
                    hosts = inv[a_child]['hosts']
                    if host in hosts:
                        return hosts[host]
    return None
```
generate_param_asic_index then calls this function with a check if it is None.
```
def generate_param_asic_index(request, dut_indices, param_type):
    logging.info("generating {} asic indicies for  DUT [{}] in ".format(param_type, dut_indices))
    tbname = request.config.getoption("--testbed")
    tbfile = request.config.getoption("--testbed_file")
    if tbname is None or tbfile is None:
        raise ValueError("testbed and testbed_file are required!")

    tbinfo = TestbedInfo(tbfile)

    asic_index_params = [DEFAULT_ASIC_ID]

    for dut_id in dut_indices:
        dut = tbinfo.testbed_topo[tbname]["duts"][dut_id]
        inv_data = get_host_data(request, dut)
        if inv_data is not None:
            if param_type == ASIC_PARAM_TYPE_ALL and ASIC_PARAM_TYPE_ALL in inv_data:
                asic_index_params = range(int(inv_data[ASIC_PARAM_TYPE_ALL]))
            if param_type == ASIC_PARAM_TYPE_FRONTEND and ASIC_PARAM_TYPE_ALL in inv_data:
                asic_index_params = inv_data[ASIC_PARAM_TYPE_ALL]
            logging.info("dut_index {} dut name {}  asics params = {}".format(
                dut_id, dut, asic_index_params))
    return asic_index_params
```

I observed the testing log seems not remove topology every time, it means the PTF container may already have the mgmt interface. Therefore, I updated the commit, and add one condition check to ignore if the mgmt interface already exists in the PTF container
```
        if MGMT_PORT_NAME not in self.cntr_ifaces:
            tmp_mgmt_if = hashlib.md5((PTF_NAME_TEMPLATE % self.vm_set_name).encode("utf-8")).hexdigest()[0:6] + MGMT_PORT_NAME
            self.add_br_if_to_docker(mgmt_bridge, PTF_MGMT_IF_TEMPLATE % self.vm_set_name, tmp_mgmt_if)
```
